text:
I am probably going to publish my:
“What has changed since Julia 1.0” blog post tomorrow or Monday.
If anyone wants to tell me i got history wrong, or that I missed some awesome feature the PR is at <https://github.com/oxinabox/oxinabox.github.io/pull/17>

I have been working on this on and off since Nov 1st.
So many new features.

text:
No, its great.
GitHub flakes out after about 100.
and you can’t access the file view.
When apparently between you and Miguel was hit.
But it is only just over and once i resolved a few in the comment section it started working.

When ~Mose~ Chris broke it, with something like 150-200 comments I had to resolve ?50 of them in Atom before github started working again  (Atom doesn’t let you apply suggestions but unlike github itself doesn’t crash)

text:
The strategy is more complicated.
Midweek is when the fewest things are posted so if you get on the front-page you stay there the longest.
But also the number of people reading is lower too.
Conversely, Friday/Monday, has more things being posted but also more people reading.

If we are lucky we will manage to stay on the front few pages for 48 hours.
So Sunday could be a good play.

elements.text:

Midweek is when the fewest things are posted so if you get on the front-page you stay there the longest.
But also the number of people reading is lower too.

So Sunday could be a good play.

text: It's very interesting that most people think Julia's biggest problem is basic user-facing usability issues. But people really disagree about exactly WHAT those problems are

elements.text: It's very interesting that most people think Julia's biggest problem is basic user-facing usability issues. But people really disagree about exactly WHAT those problems are

text: TTFP, lack of interfaces, lack of static checking, bad testing framework, REPL-based workflow, ugly weird syntax, unpredictable performance are some of them, but not all people agree on which things matter

elements.text: TTFP, lack of interfaces, lack of static checking, bad testing framework, REPL-based workflow, ugly weird syntax, unpredictable performance are some of them, but not all people agree on which things matter

text: I suppose that is both real and valid criticisms of weak points about Julia, but also a really nice compliment: People expect it to do everything well, and complain what it doesn't. You don't hear people complain that C++'s REPL experience is lacking.

elements.text: I suppose that is both real and valid criticisms of weak points about Julia, but also a really nice compliment: People expect it to do everything well, and complain what it doesn't. You don't hear people complain that C++'s REPL experience is lacking.

text: if you'd mention "C++ REPL" on hn, people would answer "are you crazy? that's a static compiled language!"

elements.text: if you'd mention "C++ REPL" on hn, people would answer "are you crazy? that's a static compiled language!"

text: I'm fine with people complaining about concrete painpoints, what I don't like is that some people seem to go "it doesn't do x!" when in reality it does...

elements.text: I'm fine with people complaining about concrete painpoints, what I don't like is that some people seem to go "it doesn't do x!" when in reality it does...

text:
Some comparisons are really intriguing/flattering/amazing though:

>  I cannot believe that plotting an scatter plot of a few million points is so slow while AAA videogames render millions of pixels in real time.

elements.text: Some comparisons are really intriguing/flattering/amazing though:
I cannot believe that plotting an scatter plot of a few million points is so slow while AAA videogames render millions of pixels in real time.

text:
>  If you don't use REPL (and for many good reasons you shouldn't) or some other such horror, every plot is the first plot. And it's pain. And not just plots really. Doing anything in Julia is pain if you try to use it as a programming language instead of an app for buggy, unreproducible and misunderstood ad-hoc analyses.
best comment so far

elements.text: If you don't use REPL (and for many good reasons you shouldn't) or some other such horror, every plot is the first plot. And it's pain. And not just plots really. Doing anything in Julia is pain if you try to use it as a programming language instead of an app for buggy, unreproducible and misunderstood ad-hoc analyses.
best comment so far

text:
The docs say it is the preferred way.
It says (in a Note, not a Warning) interactions are "not fully worked out" but refers to the `[extras]` way as "the old way" for "1.0 and 1.1". And lists the new way first.

Docs sure do make it sound like this is the new way.

text:
<https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/v1/creating-packages/#Test-specific-dependencies-in-Julia-1.2-and-above|https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/v1/creating-packages/#Test-specific-dependencies-in-Julia-1.2-and-above>

> The exact interaction between Project.toml, test/Project.toml and their corresponding Manifest.tomls are not fully worked out, and may be subject to change in future versions.

elements.text: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/v1/creating-packages/#Test-specific-dependencies-in-Julia-1.2-and-above
The exact interaction between Project.toml, test/Project.toml and their corresponding Manifest.tomls are not fully worked out, and may be subject to change in future versions.

text:
It doesn't say experimental, it doesn't say beta.
It doesn't say "may not function correctly".
It is hardly a strong statement warning people away.

And it's in a note. No a warning. We have a warning admonition.

And it is still presented first.
And still referred to this as the way for 1.2+ in the title and the other as "the old way", for "1.0 and 1.1".

elements.text:

And still referred to this as the way for 1.2+ in the title and the other as "the old way", for "1.0 and 1.1".
